search_result.title: Frawley fans, workers cherish return Blue Rocks, minor league ...
search_result.text:
Kevin McDermott was in Frawley Stadium on Sept. 14, 2019, when the Blue Rocks won the Carolina League baseball championship.

On Tuesday night, he wore a T-shirt commemorating that victory, and it probably felt rather ancient.

He hadn’t been back to the Wilmington Riverfront ballpark since and the absence left a void.

“It was heart-breaking,” the Wilmington resident said.

COVID-19 shut down the 2020 minor league baseball season, leaving Frawley Stadium primarily to a few amateur leagues and the eyes of passersby on I-95.

But when the 2021 season belatedly began Tuesday, with the Blue Rocks in a revamped league and under new big-league affiliation, McDermott spoke for just about all who came through the turnstiles.

“It feels great to be back seeing live baseball,” he said.

The Blue Rocks are at the same competitive level where they’ve dwelled since their 1993 rebirth when Frawley Stadium opened on the new Wilmington Riverfront. That’s three steps from the big leagues in the new 12-team High-A East.

They are now affiliated with the Washington Nationals. The Blue Rocks had been part of the Kansas City Royals’ organization since 1993 except for two seasons (2005-06) with the Boston Red Sox.

ROCK ON: Blue Rocks survive MiLB upheaval

But there is no more Carolina League, which was the Blue Rocks’ home from 1993 through 2019, when they won their fifth title but first since 1999. Presumably, they get to keep the Mills Cup championship trophy for good.

The 2019 expiration of the Professional Baseball Agreement between Major League Baseball and Minor League Baseball led to a trimmed-down farm system consisting of just four affiliated levels. Leagues are now named simply by geographic location.

The Blue Rocks are one of five teams in the High-A East’s North Division with Tuesday’s visitor from down I-95, Maryland’s Aberdeen IronBirds (Orioles), along with the Jersey Shore Blue Claws (Phillies), and New York’s Brooklyn Cyclones (Mets) and Hudson Valley Renegades (Yankees). The South’s Winston-Salem (N.C.) Dash are the only remaining Carolina League outfit at this level.

As fans streamed up the stairs into the stadium Tuesday night, ticket takers Gwen Coughlin and Dave Houtman greeted them with a year’s worth of pent-up enthusiasm.

“When they said they weren’t gonna open [last year], I was broken-hearted,” said Houtman, an energetic 84-year-old from suburban Newark. “I cannot just sit around and do nothing. I’m afraid I’d get fat and die and I don’t want to do that.”

Stadium capacity is presently limited to 25% with seating pods of two, three or four. Attendance Tuesday night was 1,381.

Face coverings are also required except when food and beverages are being consumed.

Houtman was starting his 25th year working Blue Rocks games, coming back each spring because of the joy he gets being around people who are just happy to be at the ballpark.

“When they come in, most of them are just tickled to death to be back here,” Houtman said.

To limit travel with the COVID-19 pandemic still lingering, teams will play six-game series that run from Tuesday through Sunday with Monday as an off day.

DIAMOND JUBILEE: Midway honors Little League’s oldest coach

It’s a 120-game schedule, as opposed to the previous 140 games, and runs from May 4 through Sept. 19. The Phillies’ Blue Claws visit next week with former St. Mark’s High and University of Delaware pitcher Billy Sullivan on the staff.

Wilmington resident Coughlin was practically moved to tears, she admitted, by the opening night fanfare and the reunion with her co-workers.

“This is like Christmas for me,” she said. “It was really, really tough last year. No games. A few of us used to get together in the parking lot with masks and we just met because this is like our family. I missed everybody dearly, just the whole electric atmosphere of the game.”

The Blue Rocks’ starting pitcher Tuesday night was Jackson Rutledge, who was Washington’s No. 1 pick, 17th overall, in the 2019 draft out of San Jacinto Junior College in Texas.

He didn’t have a 2020 season but did earn an invite to the Nationals’ alternate site in Fredericksburg, Virginia, after the big-league season started in July. Before that, he’d tried to stay fit at home, including lifting buckets of cement purchased at Home Depot for strength training, said his mother, Susan.

Susan Rutledge was wearing her son’s red Nationals jersey from that 2020 summer stint in Fredericksburg in her seat down the right-field line Tuesday night after flying in for the game from St. Louis near the family’s Missouri home.

“He’s very excited just to get into the routine of playing games, just getting back on the field,” she said.

“It feels like home, really,” she said of being at the ballpark with husband Josh. “We’re really excited to be here.”

Rutledge was one of the few bright spots in Tuesday’s 10-1 loss in which the Blue Rocks managed just three hits. The 6-foot-8 right-hander allowed three hits and two earned runs while walking three and whiffing four in 4⅔ innings.

Blue Rocks manager Tommy Shields and players were not available for postgame interviews.

Nearly 200 modern Blue Rocks have gone on to play in the majors, including standouts such as Carlos Beltran, Johnny Damon and Zack Greinke and several members of Red Sox and Royals World Series champions.

A previous Wilmington Blue Rocks franchise played in the Interstate League from 1940-52 at the since-razed Wilmington Ball Park at 30th Street and Gov. Printz Blvd. That team was tied in with the Philadelphia Athletics from 1940-43 and Phillies from 1944-52 and featured future Hall-of-Fame pitcher Robin Roberts.

Fans had to wait 41 years for the return of the Rocks in 1993. The one-year pandemic-imposed hiatus of 2020 was far shorter but, because of its unexpected and unprecedented nature, equally unwelcomed.

Because of COVID protocols, the between-innings antics and contests are temporarily absent.

But baseball is back, and that’s what mattered most.

“I missed this,” Houtman said as he prepared to scan another ticket bar code. “I don’t know how I did without this to tell you the truth.’’

There was no guarantee Wilmington would still have a team after MLB’s hostile takeover.

But the Blue Rocks were Tuesday night, though surprisingly still wearing uniforms trimmed in the Royals’ navy blue and sky blue rather than the Nationals’ navy blue and red.

“I’m glad they came back,” McDermott said.

New loop

The Carolina League is no more. The Blue Rocks are still at the same level, three steps from the majors, in a league simply called High-A East.

North Division

Aberdeen (Md.) IronBirds (Orioles)

Brooklyn Cyclones (Mets)

Hudson Valley (N.Y.) Renegades (Yankees)

Jersey Shore (N.J.) Blue Claws (Phillies)

Wilmington Blue Rocks (Nationals)

South Division

Asheville (N.C.) Tourists (Astros)

Bowling Green (Ky.) Hot Rods (Rays)

Greensboro (N.C.) Grasshoppers (Pirates)

Greenville (S.C.) Drive (Red Sox)

Hickory (N.C.) Crawdads (Rangers)

Rome (Ga.) Braves (Braves)

Winston-Salem (N.C.) Dash (White Sox)

Riverfront attractions

Since the last Blue Rocks game at Frawley Stadium in September of 2019, the Wilmington Riverfront has become more accessible due to the opening of the Senator Margaret Rose Henry Bridge linking the area with Route 13 near the Chase Fieldhouse.

The Riverfront has numerous attractions and restaurants worth visiting before or after games.

They include Riverwalk Mini-Golf, the Delaware Sports Museum and Hall of Fame, the DuPont Environmental Education Center and the Delaware Children’s Museum, which is expected to open in June.

Two new Riverfront hotels – Hyatt Place and Homewood Suites by Hilton – have joined the Westin, which flanks the busy Chase Center on the Riverfront.

Restaurants include the Iron Hill Brewery, Big Fish Grill and Timothy’s Riverfront Grill close to Frawley Stadium plus several others, including the Constitution Yards Beer Garden, a short walk away.

The nearby Delaware Theatre Company provides a non-sports entertainment venue.

search_result.title: What a Purzycki administration might look like
search_result.text:
Christina Jedra

The News Journal

Mike Purzycki won the Democratic nomination to become Wilmington mayor.

He faces a Republican and Independent candidate in the November election.

Some residents feel Purzycki doesn't understand their plight, a fact he seeks to change.

Mike Purzycki acknowledged his challenge on Tuesday after his first speech as the Democratic nominee for Wilmington mayor.

The head of the Riverfront Development Corp. received more than half his votes from the area surrounding his neighborhood, the Highlands, a wealthy area not plagued by the violence and poverty elsewhere in the city.

“I still have to introduce myself in many places so they start trusting not only my methods but my objectives and my heart,” he said during his speech at the Chase Center on the Riverfront, the special events facility his group helped shepherd into existence along the waterfront. “That’s something that’s going to take time.”

Purzycki, who beat seven opponents in the primary, will appear on the general election ballot with two others, but his primary victory means he will almost certainly become the mayor of heavily Democratic Wilmington in November. His status as the executive director of the RDC helped him gain credibility as someone who could bring money into the city. But some people who live in neighborhoods away from the Riverfront, where tens of millions of dollars were invested, feel Purzycki doesn't understand their plight.

“He doesn't have strong ties within many of the neighborhoods,” said Kathleen Patterson, president of the 2nd District Neighborhood Planning Council, which represents the Triangle neighborhood. “Many people are wary of corporate managers and that is the background many residents attach to him.”

That could cause an uphill battle for Purzycki connecting with constituents. The next mayor of Wilmington will be inheriting a ninth-floor City Hall office looking out onto a community with a nearly 7 percent unemployment rate, 110 shootings this year and ongoing concerns about businesses leaving.

Republican opponent Robert Martin said Purzycki is "out of touch" with Wilmingtonians.

“Some of the people shot on these streets, I knew them personally," he said.

Purzycki, who previously served on the New Castle County Council, admits his challenge is making headway in the community to close divisions and restoring the mayor's office, which has been hit by resident frustration under the administration of Dennis P. Williams, who finished fourth in Tuesday's primary.

By improving the infrastructure of the city, Purzycki believes he can change the culture of violence. He was named executive director of the RDC in 1996, and the group is credited with bringing restaurants, shops and attractions to what had been a run-down section of the Christina River.

As mayor, Purzycki envisions a city with facades illuminated with light, bustling restaurants downtown, bike lanes on Union Street and cranes throughout the city building new residences and business spaces, he told The News Journal.

“I want people to come into the city and be struck by how beautiful it is,” he said.

Whereas Williams, a former police officer, campaigned on promises he would lower the crime rate, Purzycki says improving the foundation of the city will change mindsets. He said the crime rate will follow suit.

“Culture trumps strategy every time,” he said.

Bridging the gap

The father of two adult children, Purzycki, 71, lives with his wife in the Highlands where they also are raising a 14-year-old.

He defeated incumbent Williams and six others with significant help from 1,673 votes (more than half of his 2,968 total) around his neighborhood, City Council District 8. He did not win any other district, but his moderate support throughout the city coupled with his showing at home led him to the nomination with just 23 percent of the vote — 234 votes ahead of Eugene Young and 415 over Kevin Kelley.

The Highlands, in the northwest part of the city near Greenville, is in a ZIP code with million-dollar homes and nearly nonexistent crime.

Some observers think Purzycki has a chance to unite the various factions that developed during the hard-fought campaign.

The jam-packed ballot and limited would-be voters meant the candidates had to fight for a very narrow piece of the electorate that was already tiny. Williams, after all, won the 2012 primary with 4,244 votes. Purzycki allies saw a window in non-Democrats. The group “Republicans and Independents for Mike" was started to send mailers and make phone calls.

"It is no secret that the next mayor will be a Democrat and will be chosen in the Sept. 13 primary,” read a letter on the group’s website. “Our only option is to switch parties.”

It was signed by Jane Castle, the wife of Mike Castle, the last Republican Delaware governor.

Registered Democrats in Delaware's largest city outnumber Republicans 5 to 1, and the party has dominated the city since the 1950s. The split means the primary acts as a de facto general election, all but guaranteeing the winner will go on to victory in November.

Still, some residents are cautiously optimistic about a possible Purzycki administration.

The Rev. Sandra Ben, president of the Northeast Civic Association, said she invited Purzycki to civic meetings and walkabouts with a group called Safe United Neighborhoods, but she has yet to hear from him.

“I am hoping that he will be more visible in the Northeast area,” she said, adding that citizens should be involved in the new mayor’s decision-making process. “I am hoping that he sees the need to involve and support all the civic associations and nonprofit organizations like S.U.N. that have been working in the trenches already to help make a difference, especially in keeping our youth off the streets.”

Greg Luna, president of the Cool Spring-Tilton Neighborhood Association, said his community has benefited from community policing and is pleased that Purzycki supports it. He urged Purzycki, if elected in the fall, to return to neighborhoods where he struggled in the primary.

“It can be one of the most challenging situations for an elected official,” Luna said. “However, if he returns to those communities with tangible accomplishments that benefit those same communities, he will do well.”

Leroy Tice is a Wilmington attorney who, with Purzycki, serves on the board of the Hope Commission, a community betterment association founded by former Mayor James Baker. Tice said the candidate will have to earn the trust of residents who question whether he can be a mayor to the whole city — but he has no doubt that he will.

Rochester, Bonini, Purzycki secure victories

Mike Purzycki wins Wilmington mayoral primary

“Forming an impression about Mike Purzycki in 30 seconds, what information would you have? That he spent some time at the Riverfront, which is a mere slice of this city,” Tice said.

When Tice first met Purzycki, he was impressed by his accomplishments but questioned his involvement in the Hope Commission.

“Why is this man, who could be anywhere in the world he wants to be, sitting in Hope Commission meetings, and why is he the lead of every project? I’ll admit I asked that question. And the answer I’ve come to is that is who he is,” he said.

Tice, who is black, criticized “African-American leadership” who engaged in “the politics of division” during the primary campaign. He said the city should “leave the doubt and cynicism at home.”

“Mike has defined himself,” he said. “He is committed to the issues that matter — and the issues he’s committed to most are the ones that matter most to those who don’t look like him.”

Making the city safe

Purzycki, who also led in the fundraising race among the eight candidates, said if he was elected his administration would tackle crime holistically. In addition to community policing, he said he would focus on strengthening the foundation of neighborhoods with what he calls a “neighborhood stabilization strategy.”

A team of representatives from the police, license and inspections, public works, and parks departments — and potentially state health and social services — would be assigned to an area, Purzycki said.

“That team then becomes accountable for behaviors and statistical incidents within a particular area,” he said. “That way, everybody owns it. They’re responsible for its appearance, for the crime, for the parks.”

The team would manage a range of issues, from crime to overflowing sewage and overgrown weeds, he said.

“When you feel the sting of failure, you’re going to be part of the solution,” he said. “If everybody keeps blaming someone else, nobody gets things done.”

Rochester, Bonini, Purzycki secure victories

Clear fundraising leaders emerge in primary races

Public safety was a central issue in the campaign and a key criticism of the Williams administration. The mayor has repeatedly come under fire for not reining in street violence, which has garnered national attention. Newsweek infamously wrote about the city’s struggles in a December 2014 story headlined “Murder Town USA (AKA Wilmington, Delaware)" and ABC had considered creating a legal drama called “Murder Town” set in the city.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention last year issued a historic report of gun violence in Wilmington, saying the shootings amounted to a public health issue. The crime issue has raised concerns that major corporations would leave the city. The Legislature and Gov. Jack Markell created a special panel, the Wilmington Public Safety Strategies Commission, to address the problem and make recommendations.

There have been 17 fatal shootings this year. Last year saw 151 shooting victims citywide and 26 killed.

Williams, who was unavailable to comment for this article, has said the Police Department has put measures in place, including a real-time crime center to identify hotspots and the hiring of former Philadelphia police Chief Charles Ramsey as a consultant.

Williams also was criticized for refusing to accept $1.5 million in state assistance for additional police patrols because lawmakers wanted to know where officers would be deployed. They also wanted the city to implement the safety commission’s suggestions. The mayor, who spent 17 years representing North Wilmington in the state Legislature, has said state lawmakers were trying to take over the Police Department.

“As an elected official who has assumed the responsibility of maintaining our home rule and ability to govern, I have taken offense to the senseless and unfair stipulations placed on Wilmington. The city of Wilmington is not for sale!” Williams wrote in a December Facebook message.

Treating a city infested with crime and blight takes time. Some residents want to see immediate changes.

Verna T. Johnson has been president of the River Commons Apartments Resident Council, near Compton Park, for 15 years. Her message to city leaders: “Get some recreation to get these kids out of the street. That’s why they run around in gangs. They don’t have no place to go.”

Michelle Harlee, president of the Compton Park Homeowners Association and a City Council candidate, also wants to see more assistance for young people.

"The 4th District would like the next mayor to work with the community to provide more resources for youth services after school and more diverse businesses at the riverfront and downtown," she said.

Developing Wilmington

Purzycki envisions an “aggressive rebuilding program” for the city and said drivers entering the city shouldn’t see “10-foot high weeds and a rusted fence.”

“That suggests to you that there’s someone who neglects it,” he said.

Purzycki said the development model employed at the Riverfront could be duplicated throughout the city. The first step is to create a zoning overlay so that certain buildings, like warehouses in the case of the waterfront, are not permitted. Then he would tackle blight, and install infrastructure, like the riverwalk and the Tubman-Garrett Riverfront Park.

“You start to create the string that would have the pearls attached,” he said.

Purzycki finds strength in neighborhood voters

Primary ushers in new look for Wilmington City Council

From there, businesses and restaurants will come, he said. Slowly.

Purzycki said places like Constitution Yards, a seasonal beer garden that opened in June, add value to neighborhoods.

“It’s just alive and it’s fun and you feel like this is a real live city,” he said. “This is the stuff I’m so proud of.”

Bobby Mieczkowski, president of the Bayard Square Neighborhood Association, said “anyone would have been an improvement over the current administration,” but he believes Purzycki’s business skills will have a trickle-down effect.

Attracting businesses "is something that can positively affect so many parts of the city and give the administration the tools and money to drive change,” he said.

In August, there were 2,334 people unemployed in Wilmington, which has a 6.8 percent unemployment rate, not seasonally adjusted, according to the Delaware Department of Labor. That rate was 5 percent nationally in August, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

“As long as you’ve got huge economic disparities, there is no bringing people together,” Purzyki said. “The way to bring people together is for them to share the prosperity, start to have the same attitude about life, taxes and governance.”

Restaurants and entertainment could also be key to job creation in Wilmington, particularly downtown, he said. There are about a dozen Riverfront restaurants that each employ 80 to 100 people, said Purzycki, who in mayoral debates was criticized for appearing concerned about job-creation on the waterfront, not citywide.

Purzycki’s plan for the city includes a high level of residential construction that will open the door for "hundreds and hundreds of jobs" like roofing, painting and masonry. He would like to see an apprenticeship program that graduates to professional work.

The city would also benefit from “enterprise and opportunity zones” in which new companies would locate to the city and receive tax and regulatory inducements for hiring locals, Purzycki said. Garasches Lane in Southbridge could be one such location, he said.

“It’s a pretty wide-reaching plan for economic development with the overarching belief that if you don’t get people working, none of this is going to work.”

Transitioning to a new administration

During some mayoral forums, Democratic candidates spoke about ousting city officials. Purzycki declined to comment on who he would replace but indicated there would be turnover if he takes office.

“Any new mayor is going to want to bring in his own team,” he said. “It’s not just the Police Department. That’s going to be the Planning Department, public works and everybody else. You want to assemble a team of people who share your view of how to make the city better.”

Purzycki acknowledged there are city departments of which he doesn’t have independent knowledge, like the Police Department. He said he would hire leadership he trusts and give them the freedom to do their jobs.

“I’m not going to tell people how to do their business any more than I tell my cardiologist how I want him to take care of my heart surgery,” he said.

Purzycki said for some positions, he may search outside the city or state.

Baker, who was mayor for three terms, advised the new mayor to hire people with governmental experience.

“I don’t care how smart you are, if you don’t understand city government and the rules and limitations it has, you’ll get yourself in trouble,” he said.

U.S. Sen. Tom Carper, D-Delaware, said Purzycki should hire his runner-up Young, the advocacy director for the Delaware Center for Justice. Young is a former aide to another U.S. senator — Cory Booker, of New Jersey.

Young and Purzycki clashed several times during debates, most notably when the eventual nominee questioned whether the 33-year-old wasn't proven enough to run the city.

“My hope is he’ll reach out to Eugene Young and find a significant role for Eugene to play in a new administration,” said Carper, who attended Purzycki's Tuesday night victory party at the Chase Center. “Eugene is a bright young man. … He’s a keeper.”

Young responded in a statement by saying, "After putting all my heart and energy into this race I'm taking this time to talk with my family and colleagues about what the future looks like."

Carper, who lives in Wilmington's Brandywine Hills neighborhood, said the primary election yielded “a lot of new blood” and will result in city, county and state representatives “that will work as one.” Communication and collaboration suffered under the Williams administration, Carper said, but Purzycki can help mend ties.

“This guy knows how to work with people,” he said. “That’s a big key to getting things done.”

Ed Osborne, Williams’s campaign manager, said if elected, Purzycki may struggle with the challenges of the job.

“I think he’ll find being the mayor of Wilmington and sitting on the ninth-floor is different than working from the Chase Center making choices on his own,” he said. “I think his heart is in the right place. He believes he can fix the crime like Dennis thought he could four years ago. I thought Dennis could fix it. It’s not an easy fix.”

Purzycki's general election opponents say the fight isn't over.

Steven Washington, the independent candidate and a Wilmington native, said he can provide inclusion that the other candidates cannot.

"Some people are hurting and they don’t feel like they’re included in the process," he said. "With me, we’ll include them anytime we have to make a decision. I’m there for the people. I’m all about our community."

Baker, who is 74 and still lives in Wilmington, said the only true test of campaign promises is enacting them.

“It’s nice to get the fanfare," he said, "but once you raise your hand and do the oath of office, here it comes.”

Reporter James Fisher contributed to this story.

search_result.title: Hotel boom brewing on Wilmington Riverfront
search_result.text:
Scott Goss, and Christina Jedra

The News Journal

Delaware's hotel industry may be about to flourish along the Wilmington Riverfront.

Developers are racing to break ground on two high-rise projects, with a third slated to follow in the coming years.

Collectively, the new hotels are expected to add 400 rooms – a three-fold increase to the once-neglected industrial area that has become a model of urban redevelopment in Delaware.

The sudden surge of development is being hailed as a potential boon to local retailers and restaurants while promising to push the Chase Center – the city's largest event space – into the next level of convention bookings.

"People are very optimistic," said Megan McGlinchey, executive director of the Riverfront Development Corp. "More rooms will mean more people visiting the riverfront and that's going to generate more business for everyone."

Learn more: Best wedding loans

RELATED: Another Riverfront? Wilmington to restore Brandywine brownfield

RELATED: Christina bike bridge to open unused pathways

A new development team surprised Delaware's hotel industry this week by announcing plans for a seven-story, 122-room hotel and banquet hall attached to the existing Big Fish Grill on the Riverfront. The project was not on the radar of most hoteliers – a rarity among a relatively small community that typically catches wind of new developments well in advance.

The project is being undertaken by Riverfront Hotel, a limited liability corporation made up of Pennsylvania-based property developer Onix Group and Big Fish Restaurant Group, a Rehoboth Beach-based chain with 11 eateries in three states – including the 275-seat seafood restaurant on the west bank of the Christina River.

"We've always had demand for a banquet space that can hold a wedding or a 200-person event," Eric Sugrue, co-founder and managing partner of the restaurant group said of his longest-running Wilmington venture. "At the end of the day, this [land] became available so I pursued it ... and it worked out to become this."

Sugrue's team says it hopes to begin construction by late summer and open a year later.

Despite the aggressive timetable, the developers say they have yet to nail down financing for their $23 million project. A general contractor has not been selected. A franchise brand name has not been secured. The lot still must be cleared of industrial contamination from more than a century of use as a shipyard. And no building permits have been issued.

"I'm a little surprised they made an announcement, frankly," said Bill Sullivan, chairman of the Greater Wilmington Convention & Visitors Bureau and managing director of the Courtyard Newark at the University of Delaware. "It sounds to me like they're still early in the process."

Even with those looming unknowns, Riverfront Hotel LLC is clearly challenging the city's largest developer.

Buccini/Pollin Group built the 180-room Westin Wilmington, a 10-story property connected to the Chase Center and presently the Riverfront's only hotel. It also has built several residential properties in the area, including the 214-unit Residences at Justison Landing, the 189-unit Residences at Harlan Flats and the 173-unit Residences at Christiana Landing on the east bank of the river.

BPG announced last year that it had been awarded franchise approval for a 100-room Homewood Suites by Hilton and was seeking a deal to open a 200-room Marriott hotel. Both projects are planned for the Riverfront, but company officials so far have declined to say exactly where – or even which side of the river – the hotels will be built.

Rob Buccini, the company's co-founder and co-president, expects to break ground on the Homewood Suites project in July, with the Marriott to follow after that hotel opens.

"There will be a little competition in the short term," he said of the Riverfront Hotel project. "But in the long term, I think that's going to benefit the city as a whole."

The big attraction

The hotel boom on the Riverfront certainly would benefit the Chase Center.

While Daniel S. Frawley Stadium, home of the Wilmington Blue Rocks, tends to catch the eyes of drivers passing by on I-95, the convention center next door is the true heart of the Riverfront – one that has evolved with each stage of the area's redevelopment.

Originally built as a 125,000-square-foot shipbuilding warehouse when the Riverfront was a thriving manufacturing center, the building was purchased by developer Verino Pettinaro in 1986 as part of a $1.2 million deal for an 86-acre swath on what by then had become an industrial wasteland.

Nearly a decade later, the property became the focal point of a major push to resurrect the fallow riverfront into an economic hub for the city. The taxpayer-backed Riverfront Development Corp. took control of the property and reopened the building in 1998 as an exhibition hall, a concept that fizzled after seven shows.

Then headed by current Mayor Mike Purzycki, the RDC sunk an additional $7 million into the building to convert the property into a mini-convention center capable of hosting small trade shows, chamber of commerce galas and weddings. But it wasn't until BPG completed the Westin that the concept really began to take off, McGlinchey said.

"Before that, we were mostly attracting local and regional groups but not much beyond Pennsylvania and New Jersey," she said. "Now we're drawing from New York to Washington, D.C., because people that attend the events can stay right next door without having to drive downtown."

The nearly $40 million Westin opened in 2014, but getting there was no easy feat.

Then-Gov. Jack Markell's administration initially considered a $6 million letter of credit for the project in 2011 before public pressure fostered by a News Journal investigation forced them to back out. An application for a $2 million state grant was entered and then withdrawn after attracting criticism from state legislators. Finally, the city and the RDC put up $3 million in loan guarantees and BPG bought less than 1-acre of property from the RDC for $2.5 million.

“The Westin was built at the bottom of the market right after the collapse,” Purzycki said. “We had to try to help these projects along. We created terms that made the financing of the project easier but didn’t give anybody any money. There were no loans. … We got all of our money back. Every single penny.”

This time around, the Riverfront hotel projects should not count on any taxpayer assistance from the city, he said.

A trickle-down effect

Now that the economy has improved and the Westin has proven the Riverfront as a viable market, there is far fewer questions about whether additional hotels would add economic development value to the Chase Center.

In fact, not having them has had the opposite effect, McGlinchey said.

"We've lost so many bookings because we didn't have the hotel rooms needed to support them," she said, citing a recent example in which a national organization of music therapists that passed on Wilmington because the city could not provide 450 hotel rooms in immediate proximity to the convention hall.

"Adding rooms would bring in a lot more groups of that size," she said. "And when you have that many people here for two or three days, they're going to spend their money locally."

More convention attendees, she added, would mean more business for the 15-screen Penn Cinema Riverfront & IMAX, the Delaware Children's Museum, Riverwalk Mini Golf, Blue Rocks games, the Riverfront Market, the Constitution Yards beer garden or Riverfront Rink and the smattering of restaurants throughout the neighborhood.

Kevin Finn, chief executive officer and co-founder of Iron Hill Brewery, said the Riverfront was on shaky ground when the restaurant opened in the early 2000s. But the Wilmington location is now one of 13 locations for the brewery in Delaware, Pennsylvania and New Jersey – and among its busiest. New hotels will keep up the momentum, he said.

“If it’s 122 rooms, it will be at least 122 people who need to eat and go out,” he said of the Riverfront Hotel LLC project.

Iron Hill often has consultants and business associates visit for meetings, he said. Usually, the customers try to stay at the Westin first, he said, but it’s “not cheap” – a one-night, one-room stay on May 6 would cost $142 – and reservations aren’t always available.

“If you don’t book a few weeks in advance, it’s hard to get a room at that hotel,” he said.

The addition of more hotel rooms also could bring even more attractions. And that, McGlichey said, could help the Riverfront lure more employers, such as AAA Mid-Atlantic, Barclay's and Navient.

"Corporations are always looking for ways to attract talent," she said. "If you have an exciting, vibrant place for them, you're going to see more of them want to come here."

The fact that more hotels may be built at the Riverfront is proof of the growing energy there, Navient spokeswoman Nikki A. Lavoie said. That nation's largest servicer of student loans moved its national headquarters to the Riverfront in 2015.

“It tells us the investment we made here two years ago was worthwhile because the area continues to grow,” she said. “We’d be really happy to welcome a new hotel as our neighbor.”

Not everyone happy

While the Riverfront might be cheering the addition of hotels, the added rooms are being looked at with some skepticism by some hoteliers.

The Delaware Hotel and Lodging Association has been warning for years that an influx of new properties throughout the state is threatening to undermine the local industry's recovery, just as it is finally getting underway.

Statewide occupancy rates returned to pre-recession levels for the first time in 2014. In 2016, those rates improved to 55 percent – still below the 60 percent break-even point for most hotels, and well south of 68 percent national average. Hotel managers say that's because a growing number of developers and hospitality chains are opening new properties every year – flooding the market with supply that outpaces demand.

The trend is even more pronounced in Wilmington, which draws most of its business from legal and corporate industries. With several banks narrowing their workforces and the DuPont Co.'s 2015 move to the suburbs, some of the four major hotels in downtown Wilmington have struggled to fill the 780 rooms among them.

Competition is expected to get even fiercer this fall when Canon Hospitality Management is slated to open a 96-room Marriott Residence Inn in the formerly vacant Beneficial Bank building at 1300 N. Market St. Soon after, BPG will begin renovating the Hotel du Pont as part of a $175 million transformation of the DuPont Building, which also includes Chemours headquarters and the Playhouse on Rodney Square.

Add in the three new hotels planned on the Riverfront, and Wilmington soon could see its overall inventory of hotel rooms jump 40 percent.

"It probably will affect my business if all three of those projects get built," said Canon Patel, president Canon Hospitality Management. "I think everyone is going to have to work on their branding, marketing strategy, and revenue management. But at the end of the day, it's going to come down to who can offer the best value proposition."

Greg Pettinaro, CEO of the family real estate company that developed several of the commercial properties on the Riverfront, said that's a battle the new hotels are likely to win.

"If I were coming from out of town, I would much rather stay on the Riverfront than downtown," he said. "You've got restaurants, movies, a 1.5-mile walking trail along the river, a nature preserve and free parking down there. Why wouldn't you chose to stay there?"

Not everyone is convinced the new hotels will harm the downtown properties, however. Bill Silva, general manager of the Westin and chairman of the state hotel association, said competition is good for everyone.

"It's going to force us all to deliver better service and provide more opportunities for people," he said. "Besides, we're still only talking about 1,200 or so rooms in the entire city. The Philadelphia Marriott has more rooms than that all by itself and they're doing fine."

McGlinchey said the new hotels would be generating new business by drawing from larger conventions at the Chase Center –– not from the existing market.

Purzycki, meanwhile, said it’s “hard to tell” if the additional properties will lead to over saturation.

“It may hurt another vendor or operator. We just don’t know,” he said. “[But] these guys are not fools. There are no novices here."

New kids on the block

The 122-room hotel planned next to Big Fish Grill will be a new undertaking for both partners in the Riverfront Hotel development team. Big Fish Restaurant Group operates eateries throughout the region but has never undertaken a hotel development project.

And the 30-year-old Onix Group – which owns six hotels, including a 96-room Comfort Inn in Rehoboth Beach – has never done a project in Wilmington. Onix also owns or is developing commercial facilities, such as the Pike Creek Medical Office Condominiums off Limestone Road, the Dover Towne Center in Kent County and a 90-bed behavioral hospital in Georgetown.

Together, the two partners make a perfect team, said Sugrue, who heads Big Fish.

"I think we're combining what we're both good at to make something great that neither of us could have accomplished on our own," he said.

The envisioned project will include a one-story, 12,000-square-foot connector with a 4,300-square-foot banquet hall that will run from the kitchen of Big Fish Grill south to an 83-foot-tall hotel topped by a bridal suite. Most of the rooms will feature unobstructed views of the Christina River and the Wilmington skyline. The new property also will include an outdoor patio along the Riverwalk path that traces the Christina's western bank.

Big Fish will operate the banquet hall, while Onix Group will manage the hotel. The project is expected to employ 60 workers. Construction would create 175 jobs.

"We're looking to market to the mid-priced leisure and business traveler," said Jonathan Silver, the Onix Group's director of real estate. "We think our hotel will be a nice compliment to the Westin, which is a different price point. There's a demand here for that kind of modern, affordable accommodation."

Rob Buccini said he welcomes the competition but adds that he would prefer a "higher-end brand."

"I think the Riverfront is big enough for both of us," he said. "For us to keep building the momentum in Wilmington, there definitely needs to be other developers focused on the city along with us."

Developer Louis Capano III also is heeding that call with his first foray into the city. Louis Capano & Sons recently began work on a 68-unit, multifamily apartment building at 101 Avenue of the Arts, next to the Gates Building, which houses Barclay's and FireStone Roasting House. That four-story project is slated to be followed by an eight-story structure with 135 apartments.

"Buccini/Pollin has really spurred a lot of the growth along the river and proven there is high demand among people who want to live there," Capano said. "I think that has encouraged other people like us to invest right alongside them."

Silver also praised BPG's contribution to the Riverfront.

"I have a ton of respect for them and what they've done for this city," he said. "They're as first class as it gets."

Purzycki described BPG as “our heroes” for investing more than a $1 billion in the city over the last decade, both along the Riverfront and North Market Street. But, he said, it’s even more encouraging to see fresh blood investing in Wilmington.

“It’s important that we get other investors, other large developers, committing their funds into the city,” he said. “To me, that’s a sign of confidence in the future of the city. That is very healthy for us.”

Megan Earl has clocked the drive.

It takes 37 seconds to get from the sign outside the Barrett Farm residential development in Magnolia where she lives to the sign outside the new David E. Robinson Elementary School that she thought her soon-to-be fourth grader would be attending during the 2021-22 school year.

The route is less than 1 mile.
